Here is a not-so-fun but related story, courtesy of Bigclive:
There was an event in a club of sorts. They had decked the place out with clear fluorescent lighting tubes that emitted a dim, actually pretty „clubbish“ light. Over the next few days, people started showing up at their doctors because of pain and itchiness their eyes, blurred vision, and in some cases redness and inflammation of their skin.
Long story short: the club owner had (unknowingly...he just did not seem to know better) bought a truckload of UV-C tubes to light his venue. It gave a buch of people sunburns and „welders‘ flash“, which is basically a bad sunburn to the back of the eye.

The videos failed to mention that in those areas of Earth which get more hours of exposure to sunlight throughout the year, the people living there (generally) have darker skin. This being due because of the balance of needs for getting vitamin D from the sun and protection from skin damage. So in areas with less hours of sunlight, lighter skin means the priority shifts to getting as much vitamin D within the limited sun exposure, at the expense of skin damage during Summer time. This all happening over millennia. Now people can get vitamin D from milk (and other food) fortified with vitamin D, and if necessary take addition vitamin D pills on the advice of their doctors. (I've read that the quality of vitamin D obtained from sun exposure is superior to that from pills and that vitamin D helps prevent some cancers.)

"Clouds are denser pockets of water vapor and dust that are good at blocking sunlight."

Argh, no. The most important feature of clouds are the suspended liquid water droplets and ice crystals (that's what makes them clouds and not haze). "Water vapor and dust" may be present in clouds, but that's like saying "Steel is made up of carbon and sometimes nickel or manganese." You're missing the most important and most abundant part!
